subtitles.text: Here we go... Upokami!
This time, we're joined by Shiori Yagi of Tsubaki Factory and
and Hiko Hirayama of Angulum.
This show is about the behind-the-scenes of the production of various artists
We'll be going behind the scenes of the production of various artists belonging to the Upfront Group.
Our recording, rehearsal, etc.
We will show you the process of our recording and rehearsal.
I've been taking dance lessons to learn how to be a theater actress.
I've always loved musicals, so I've been going to see a lot of musicals.
I have always wanted to be a part of musicals, and I had studied voice and ballet.
I have been taking dance lessons mainly in hip-hop and other genres that would be useful for Tsubaki Factory's activities.

I used to take dance lessons mainly in hip-hop and other genres that would be useful for Tsubaki Factory's activities, but recently I've been taking a lot of lessons in the musical genre with the aim of becoming a musical dancer.
I've been looking up a lot of videos and I found out that they use hats, and hats, and hats, and hats, and hats.
I've been taking a lot of lessons in the musical genre.
I've been taking a lot of lessons in the musical genre lately.
I was impressed by the wide range of dances that were performed in stage costumes, and I was also interested in trying them out myself.
I, Hirayama, am studying how to dance at festivals such as Countdown Japan.
Oh, yes, I recently participated in a festival called "Countdown Japan" with Angstrom.
I recently performed at a festival called Countdown Japan with Angulum.
I performed at a festival called "Countdown Japan" with Angulum.

The teacher who put on the sales pitch was different from usual, and he encouraged the audience in a different way than usual. I usually dance in formation, but I would break it up and sing and sing with the microphone pointed at everyone.

At festivals, there are people who don't know Angstrom, so I felt that there are many ways to stir up the crowd and to make them stop and look at the stage, so I'd like to study them. I would like to study that.

Yes, Red Line is a new song, but it is the first song with 11 members, including two new members, Miyukiho Shimoita and Hana Goto, so there are many fresh voices in this song,

In the lyrics of this song, there is a red line that must not be crossed, a line that one wants to cross but cannot, or a line that one wants to cross but must not, and the song is full of such conflicting feelings,
This piece has a long solo part, and there are many solo parts. The first part is of course connected to the solo part, and the chorus is also connected to the solo part, which I think is very rare,
It has a lot of modulations,
It is one of the freshest songs in Angulum's repertoire.

I have a voice that always has vibrato,
It's a different voice from mine, so it's very fresh to listen to,
I always think it's great, and it was a very cool recording.

It's time to say goodbye to Apkami, brought to you by Shiori Yagi and Yuki Hirayama!
We've seen a lot of different images this time, but for me, Hirayama, the vocal recording of Wakana Matsumoto of Red Line left a deep impression.
She is the member who sings the "D-melody" or the very calm part of the Red Line's interlude.
I could see the way she sings in her usual songs, so I was able to see how she recorded the song.
I was also able to see Matsumoto-san's sharp singing style, which is different from her usual singing style and has a stronger edge to it.
I, Yagi, was impressed by Rei Inoue's vocal recording.

Thank you very much! In Upfront Group, we're going to take you behind the scenes of the production of various artists belonging to Upfront Group.
Please subscribe to our channel and we'll introduce you to the parts you don't normally see.
This time on Apkami, we'll be talking with Shiori Yagi of Tsubaki Factory and Yuki Hirayama of Angulum.
